title: Did the Confederate States allow the importation of slaves? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: The 7-state CSA tried hard to drag in Virginia, including offering to move the capital to Richmond, keeping purchase of slaves from Virginia legal, keeping competition from foreign slave imports illegal, and hurrying to fire on Fort Sumter while the Virginia Secession Convention was still in secession, offering the first chance to light a cannon to a visiting Virginian. Adding 4 Upper South states doubled the CSA’s white population, more than doubled industry, and Virginia and Tennessee suffered the largest number of battles. If this hadn’t worked, Kentucky’s border state convention scheduled for next month would have advocated a neutral bloc against overland war, which would have channeled the war towards naval landings in the Deep South. After Virginia’s sudden secession, Kentucky continued alone with neutrality for months, then joined the Union side after Confederates invaded first. Even with limited emphasis, naval attacks were a successful part of the early war, capturing the largest city New Orleans, as well as Port Royal in South Carolina and numerous other ports.

The Confederate constitution prohibited the importation of slaves except from the United States while reserving for the Confederate Congress the authority to ban importation of slaves from the United State if they chose to at a later date. As with the United States Constitution the local slave breeders didn’t want the competition from transatlantic slave ships and the Confederacy didn’t want to bump heads with the British Empire which was really down on slave trafficking by that point.

Before the Civil War, a number of the more radical ““fire-eating” slavery advocates wanted to re-legalize the international slave trade from Africa, which the U.S. had banned since 1808. However, when the Confederate government was formed, it was dominated by less radical people who opted to retain the slave trade ban. Among the reasons for this: Virginia, a prospective Confederate state, made money exporting its excess slaves to other slave states and didn’t want competition from Africa.The Confederacy wanted support from Great Britain which had taken a strong stance against the international slave tradeAnd, I would hope. at least some Confederates recognized that the African slave trade was even more morally horrified than slavery itself, since it involved people being torn away from their homes and while societies and then, often, perishing on the ship voyage to America.

Of course, but there was a very effective Union blockade, and slave ships are really hard to use for smuggling due to … the horrific stench, actually. You could smell them downwind ten miles or more. Hundreds of people crammed together - in tiers. They relieved themselves onto the people below them, they vomited onto the people below them. And there was little fresh air, so the poor wretches just sweated and sweated, in filth. And they died like flies.

No. The United States had actually outlawed the importation of slaves into the country in 1808. Any slaves brought into the country after that would have been through illegal smuggling. The CSA maintained the ban. The last known shipload of slaves successfully into The South was in 1860. Any attempt after that would have been thwarted by Union and British blockades.

“Did the Confederate States allow the importation of slaves?” From where? Certainly not Africa. Decades before the British outlawed the slave trade and used its navy to back that up. The CSA was not going to anger Britain over slaves. Individuals may have had money to purchase slaves among themselves, but the CSA needed money for more important things
No, it was strictly forbidden. But the North continued shipping slaves from Africa to Brazil until1888. The North really had no problems with profiting off Slavery, they just hated living with Blacks

No. Their laws did not allow it, and the Union Navy prevented it. In the last half of the Civil War, the prices of slaves declined, reducing the incentive to import against the law. The British Royal Navy may have been patrolling the West Coast of Africa by this time.
They did not prohibit it but they did not need to import as they were able to breed an adequate supply at home.
